en_results: presence among them, so unwelcome? I am not a man to be feared, I am not a man
en_results_raw: presence among them, so unwelcome? I am not a man to be feared, I am not a man to be hated. I am but a humble servant of the crown, and I have done no wrong to any of them. And yet, they look at me with such disdain, such contempt. It is a puzzle, a riddle that I fear I shall never unravel. But I shall not be swayed by their displeasure, I shall not be deterred from my duty. I shall continue to serve the crown, to the best of my ability, and I shall not be intimidated by the Malfoys, or any other. For I am a man of honor, a man of principle, and I shall not be swayed by the whims of others.

He had always been the one to avoid danger, to sidestep and weave, to talk his way out of trouble. But now, as he sat in the dimly lit room, his finger throbbing in time with his pulse, he couldn't help but think that perhaps he should have paid more attention to that particular lesson. Not that it would have made a difference, of course - he still wouldn't have been able to cast the spell, not with his magic bound as it was. But still, it was a useful skill to have, and one that he had never really considered important before. He sighed, and carefully wrapped a piece of cloth around the cut, trying to stem the bleeding. It was going to be a long four days.

The words on the page seemed to blur and dance before his eyes, but he couldn't tear his gaze away from the revelation that had left him reeling. He felt as though he had been punched in the gut, his breath knocked out of him, and he couldn't seem to catch his breath. The room around him began to spin, and he felt a cold sweat break out on his forehead as the truth sank in. He thought back to all the times he had trusted, all the times he had believed, and a wave of nausea washed over him. He felt betrayed, deceived, and more than a little scared. The world he thought he knew had just been turned upside down, and he wasn't sure how to right it again.

His eyes twinkled with warmth as he surveyed the gathering, his gaze lingering on each face as if searching for something or someone. The atmosphere was heavy with anticipation, the air thick with the weight of unspoken questions and unresolved tensions. The figures that had appeared were all familiar, yet somehow different, their faces etched with a mix of emotions - fear, excitement, curiosity. They seemed to be waiting for something, or someone, to break the silence that had fallen over the group like a shroud. And then, just as it seemed that the tension could not be stretched any further, a figure emerged from the shadows, tall and imposing, with eyes that seemed to bore into the very soul.

en_second_half: swerve out of sight to avoid the deadly trail of flame, and at the same time felt the sidecar sway ominously: Its metal connections to the bike had splintered with the force of acceleration.
en_results: scattering in all directions as the motorbike, its tires screeching in protest, took the corner of the street with a reckless abandon that left Harry's heart in his throat. The wind whipped through
en_results_raw: scattering in all directions as the motorbike, its tires screeching in protest, took the corner of the street with a reckless abandon that left Harry's heart in his throat. The wind whipped through his hair, his eyes streaming with tears, as he clung to the back of the bike, his fingers locked in a death grip on the rider's waist. The Death Eaters, their faces twisted with rage and frustration, gave chase, their own motorbikes roaring as they pursued the pair through the crowded streets of London. The sound of shattering glass and crunching metal filled the air as they weaved in and out of the traffic, the motorbikes dodging and swerving with a precision that left Harry breathless. And then, in an instant, they were clear of the traffic, the motorbike surging forward with a burst of speed that left the Death Eaters far behind. The rider, his face set in a grim mask, glanced back over his shoulder, his eyes gleaming with a fierce triumph, and Harry saw, with a jolt of shock, that it was Sirius Black who was driving the motorbike.

en_first_half: He swung his legs off the sofa; he needed to see Hagrid with his own eyes before he would believe that he was alive. He had
en_second_half: barely stood up, however, when a door opened and Hagrid squeezed through it, his face covered in mud and blood, limping a little but miraculously alive.
en_results: already been fooled once by a Death Eater's disguise, and he was not about to let his desire to see Hagrid cloud his judgment. He made his way to the door,
en_results_raw: already been fooled once by a Death Eater's disguise, and he was not about to let his desire to see Hagrid cloud his judgment. He made his way to the door, his wand at the ready, and slowly turned the handle, peering out into the corridor. The coast seemed to be clear, so he slipped out of the room, his eyes scanning the shadows for any sign of movement. As he moved stealthily down the corridor, the portraits of old headmasters and headmistresses watched him pass, their eyes following him with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. He reached the staircase and began to make his way down, his heart pounding in his chest. He had to see Hagrid, had to know that he was really alive. The thought of his friend being tortured and killed by the Death Eaters was unbearable, and he couldn't shake the feeling that he was walking into a trap. But he had to try, had to know the truth. He reached the bottom of the stairs and pushed open the door to the entrance hall, his eyes scanning the room for any sign of Hagrid. And then, he saw him, standing by the front door, a huge grin spreading across his face as he caught sight of Harry. Harry's heart leapt with joy, and he rushed across the room, throwing his arms around Hagrid's waist. "Hagrid!" he exclaimed, relief and happiness washing over him. "I thought you were dead!" Hagrid chuckled, hugging him back. "I'm afraid I'm not that easy to get rid of, Harry," he said, his voice rumbling deep within his chest. Harry pulled back, looking up at Hagrid's face, taking in the sight of his friend, alive and well. He felt a lump form in his throat as he struggled to speak, but Hagrid just smiled and clapped him on the back. "Let's get out of here, Harry," he said. "We've got a lot to talk about."

The stairs creaked beneath their feet as they climbed, the sound echoing off the walls, and Ron, who was bringing up the rear, kept looking back over his shoulder, his eyes wide with fear. They reached the top of the stairs and found themselves in a long, dark corridor, the walls lined with cobweb-covered portraits, their subjects' eyes seeming to follow them as they moved. "I don't like this," Ron whispered, his voice barely audible over the sound of their own breathing. "Let's go back." But Hermione shook her head, her eyes fixed on some point ahead. "We have to keep going," she said, her voice firm, though it trembled slightly. "We have to find out what's going on."

They were a message, scrawled in haste, and they made Harry's blood run cold.

Se dio la vuelta y vio a una mujer mayor, con el pelo gris y la cara arrugada, que lo miraba con ojos tristes. Sirius se sintió incómodo y no supo qué decir. La mujer se acercó a él y le habló en un tono suave. "¿Qué haces aquí, joven?", le preguntó. Sirius intentó explicarle que estaba buscando algo, pero la mujer lo interrumpió. "No, no, no estás buscando nada. Estás buscando a alguien". Sirius se sintió confundido. "¿A quién?", preguntó. La mujer sonrió y se sentó en la cama. "A tu padrino", dijo. "¿Dónde está?", preguntó Sirius. La mujer se encogió de hombros. "No lo sé", dijo. "Pero puedo ayudarte a encontrarlo". Sirius se sintió esperanzado. "¿Cómo?", preguntó. La mujer sonrió de nuevo.
